1115973509820428288.text: And yet the biggest believers in #QE, central bankers, are the biggest critics of #MMT. Their hypocritical push-back is the main reason why this crazy theory keeps gaining, and will eventually go mainstream, forming the ultimate bull thesis for #cryptocurrency.

1115973508855685122.text: #MMT may be the 2nd worst idea in economics, but its proponents are intellectually honest. If printing money to aid a small part of society is good, how could printing money for all be bad? Fans of quantitative easing like my old friend @benbernanke should love this theory.

1095684850525392896.text: A decade ago, zero interest rates was a controversial idea. After the worst decade for middle class income in almost a century - it's become orthodoxy. Then the same experts are shocked by events like Trump or Brexit, or the rise of fringe right and left wing movements.

1095684849912946688.text: Not one such intervention has ever matched the expectations of even the most die-hard architects, and yet faith in them is now stronger than ever, proving once again that economics is the ONLY profession where the more an idea fails, the more practitioners believe them.

1095684849309024262.text: Yesterday marked the 20th anniversary of the Bank of Japan taking rates to 0, ushering in the era of money madness. Judging by the lack of growth, lack of inflation & preponderance of debt, the policy has failed. The same could be said for ZIRP & QE in the US and EU.

1091037304146272261.text: There are many reasons to own crypto, from owning a new asset class as it gets built to decentralization to trustless computing. But the original reason to buy Bitcoin is still the best: the folks in charge of the economy are bent on breaking ithttps://medium.com/@omid.malekan/the-original-crypto-bull-thesis-revisited-reinvigorated-76ac83c44ad9 …

1091037303479390215.text: It's been a good week for the original #bitcoin long thesis. The @federalreserve  just reminded us that all they really care about is the stock market, and the @ecb had the audacity to take the lie at the heart of the greatest money experiment in history and state it outright.

1090292834933133312.text: Since the cost of mining has no bearing on production, it has no bearing on price, making it a useless valuation metric. It doesn't matter what it costs Bitmain in China or Brad in Chelsea to mine BTC, we'll still get 12.5 every 10 minutes. More here:https://medium.com/@omid.malekan/jp-morgan-is-using-the-wrong-valuation-technique-on-bitcoin-65413b287763 …

1090292833804869633.text: In physical commodities, production tends to decline with price, which helps establish a floor during a decline. But with crypto, production is fixed (and continuously re-fixed via the difficulty adjustment).

1090292832802344962.text: The recent report by #JPM trying to place a fair value on #Bitcoin of $2800 (or $1200) is recycling a false valuation metric borrowed from physical commodities,  that of marginal cost pricing. But this model is useless for BTC.

1089917326978355200.text: New that like Venezuela, Iran is now also working on a national cryptocurrency adds a new twist to my belief that "criminals make great early adopters." That general fact, BTW, is not a bug but a feature of new technology-as true for cars and pagers as it is for crypto.

1088465051852382208.text: Reason #1 why Fiat #stablecoins will be a kipper app: Most people are perfectly happy with fiat money like the dollar. What they are lacking is better payment rails that aren't either absurdly slow or preposterously expensive. Blockchain solves that problem.

1048336902154321920.text: If you want a digital currency that acts like the dollar,  just tokenize dollars and be done with it. If you want decentralized money, use a cryptocoin.  Algorithmic stablecoins just combine the worst of both worlds.

1048336901135056896.text: Doing so is like watching a famous musician sign a lot of autographs, then concluding that signing autographs is all it takes to become the next Kanye.

1041779770814607361.text: The popular argument these days seems that a cryptocoin can only be X, but not Y. The counterargument is the dollar, which is the largest store of value & medium of exchange & unit of account & debt denomination & thing people make rain. Any coin can be everything, or nothing.

1041779769715642368.text: I suggest people stop trying to fit crypto into existing economic models that a)almost nobody understands b)are too abstract to be of any use and c)have not actually worked in the non-crypto economy.

1041779768616804352.text: If ETH goes to zero, #Ethereum fragments into countless individual token blockhcains, each one of which is not very secure, because the value of one token on one chain is far lower than the value of all tokens + ETH on another.

1041779767698247680.text: The abstractionist might argue that security would then be provided by the various tokens that the miners would prefer to ETH for PoW, but that's not true. One token having value does nothing to secure transactions for another token.

1041779766653845505.text: For any permissionless chain, the value of the native coin is essential to security. If it goes to zero, the blockchain becomes vulnerable to endless attack, so it's literally not possible to have "Ethereum succeed wildly but ETH become worthless"

1041779765294850051.text: I continue to be disappointed that otherwise highly intelligent people like @mikejcasey keep entertaining the flawed "economic abstraction" argument posed by the likes of @JeremyRubin about #ethereum.  Here's why:

1038205103323471872.text: Though well intentioned, Bernie’s #stopbezos act, which stands for “Stop Bad Employers by Zeroing Out Subsidies” would better be named the MoRoN Act, which stands for “More Robots Now.” Increasing labor costs for tech Cos accelerates job elimination.
